1
Zinc oxide (ZnO) films with nano-granular structure were deposited by radio-frequency magnetron sputtering. The absence of preferred orientation was verified by XRD. HAADFSTEM micrographs revealed a nanoporous structure with pore size and grain size around 10 nm. The narrowness of the pores enabled to approximate that oxygen reduction takes place at the surface of the layers. During cathodic polarization, the surface of the electrodes became rougher due to the development of nodules on the surface. The ZnO electrodes exhibit a high activity towards oxygen reduction in KOH solution (pH = 10). Rotating ring-disk electrode measurements coupled with reaction modelling allowed to quantitatively demonstrate that the direct reduction prevailed with the indirect pathway being active as well.

sections.heading: 1. Introduction
sections.text:
The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) is one of the major cathodic reactions in corrosion science and more generally in electrochemistry. Although various reaction mechanisms have been proposed in the literature depending on the electrode material and testing conditions, [1-3] a common feature consists of the competition between two parallel pathways. Oxygen can be reduced directly into hydroxyl ions (associated rate constant k1), or indirectly with hydrogen peroxide as intermediate species (rate constants k2 and k3). Hydrogen peroxide may also be chemically decomposed at the electrode surface (rate constant k4). [3,4] The (electro)chemical reaction steps can be written as follows:

Depending on the reaction pathway, the number, n, of electrons (per reduced molecule of oxygen) varies between 2 and 4. The detection of hydrogen peroxide and therefore the relevance of the indirect pathway is usually carried out by collection-based techniques, such as rotating-ring disk electrode (RRDE) [4-6] and double-channel electrode flow cell. [7-9] Ideally this is done with a smooth working electrode (where ORR takes place) that is coplanar with the collecting electrode at which oxidation of hydrogen peroxide occurs. Zinc is a metal of considerable industrial and societal interest as it serves as protective coating for steel. [10] It is widely used in the automotive and building industries. Zinc oxide (ZnO) is often found in corrosion products formed on zinc under various exposure conditions. However, its electrochemical behaviour is not well understood yet, in particular towards ORR, and there is still a debate for results obtained in immersion and under atmospheric conditions, as recalled by Cole’s recent review. [11] Different results were also obtained with native (passive) zinc oxide layers on bare zinc and thicker ZnO coatings (ca. hundreds of nanometers) that were artificially produced, as summarized below. The early work of Delahay [12] by polarography on zinc in phosphate solution at pH 6.9 showed that n was close to 2 at low overpotentials and increased to 4 at more negative potentials. This suggests a dependence of the ORR mechanism on the passive/active state of zinc. The same trend was found in other studies on zinc (or galvanized steel) in near-neutral NaCl electrolyte by linear sweep voltammetry [13-15] and in alkaline solutions using RRDE. [5,16] The electrochemical behaviour of passive zinc producing hydrogen peroxide (pathway k2) and active (reduced) zinc generating only OH- anions (pathway k1) was more recently modelled by Flitt et al. [17] The transition between passive and active states was experimentally evidenced by a reduction peak in the polarization curves (recorded potentiodynamically in the cathodic direction). [13–15,17] In contrast, on thicker ZnO films (ca. 1200 nm) prepared by electrodeposition, the ORR kinetics was found to be mostly governed by the direct reduction pathway. [18,19] Furthermore, the ORR inhibition properties of ZnO (or ZnO-containing) patinas have been reported in the literature. Thin nanostructured ZnO layers with no preferred orientation were

grown on zinc, both anodically and cathodically in NaCl electrolyte. [20,21] They were found to diminish the cathodic activity compared to that of bare zinc in near-neutral solutions. ORR activity reduction on steel substrate was also evidenced by Thébault et al. while investigating ZnO deposits at the cut-edge of galvanized steel samples using the electrochemical microcapillary cell technique. [22] A different viewpoint was proposed in the field of atmospheric corrosion where some authors have formulated the hypothesis that the degradation of zinc (and zinc alloy) coatings could be cathodically enhanced by the presence of ZnO. [23, 24] In a scanning Kelvin probe study, Nazarov et al. demonstrated an increase of surface potential of “thick” ZnO films (ca. 200 nm, prepared by thermal oxidation) [25] compared to native films (several nanometers thin) under droplets of zinc sulfate. The authors suggested a greater ability of the thick layers to reduce oxidizing species (such as O2 molecules). In contrast, Thomas et al. evidenced a protective effect of ZnO patinas grown under artificial seawater droplets. [26] The patinas exhibited a significant gradient of porosity with an open structure on the electrolyte side and a compact one close to the zinc substrate. [26 -28] A model describing the involvement of ORR in the development of such layers was proposed by Venkatraman et al. [29] One of the aims of the present study was to sputter ZnO layers exhibiting nano-granular structure (hereafter also referred to as “non-textured ZnO” or “ZnO with no preferred orientation) with no porosity or with very narrow pores. Such layers allow to approximate that oxygen reduction takes place only at the surface of the ZnO layers (as the transport of electroactive species within the pore network is too resistive) and to simplify the electrochemical modelling. The rationale for the targeted nano-granular structure is that, in the context of corrosion, it is not expected to have patinas with a well-defined texture but rather with multiple crystallographic orientations. [26] Finally, sputtering was chosen for its ability to producing thin oxide films as “model systems” in academic research with a large variety of nanostructures depending on the selected deposition parameters, such as target composition, nature of the reactive gases and power (among others). [30-38] To the best of our knowledge, no synthesis of dense nano-granular ZnO layers using “onestep” sputtering (with no annealing post-treatment) has been reported before. To obtain sputtered ZnO films with no preferred orientation, researchers modified the pressure of oxygen on the deposition procedure. [36-38] There seems to be a trend indicating that, when the O2 partial pressure is increased, more randomly-oriented grains are observed in XRD experiments. Sasi et al. deposited ZnO films on 3C-SiC-on-Si substrates by using radio-frequency (rf) magnetron sputtering technique with zinc target, changing the O2/Ar gas ratio and annealing the layers at different temperatures. [36] The authors observed that a mixture containing 50% O2 and 50%

Ar showed three peaks (100, 002, 101) on the XRD diffractogram with practically the same intensity after annealing at 600°C. No data on the crystalline structure without annealing was supplied, suggesting that the as-deposited films were probably (002)-oriented. No microstructural data on the porosity was reported. Abdallah et al. prepared ZnO thin films with rf-magnetron sputtering (with zinc oxide target) using glass as substrate and varying the oxygen flow rate. [37] No post-deposition heat-treatment was done. They observed that increasing the flux of O2 resulted in the decrease of the (002) orientation and in the appearing of the (100) reflection. No reliable microstructural information was reported. Maslyk et al. synthesized Zn/ZnO films with DC magnetron sputtering (with zinc target) by increasing the gas flow rates while keeping the same 10:1 Ar:O2 ratio. [38] Due to the limited amount of oxygen, the produced films were essentially made of zinc. Yet it is interesting to observe from cross-sectional SEM micrographs that the porosity of the layers decreases with increasing oxygen flow rate. In this work, oxygen reduction was investigated on sputtered ZnO layers exhibiting nanogranular structure and pore size in the nanometer range (<10-15 nm). The ZnO films were characterized by XRD, Raman microscopy, XPS, SEM, EDX and HAADF-STEM Oxygen reduction was investigated using RRDE, chronoamperometry and potentiodynamic voltammetry. The ratio between direct and indirect oxygen reduction was quantitatively evaluated using reaction mechanism modelling.

Ω is the RRDE rotation rate and N the collection efficiency. ZO2 and ZHO2- are the diffusion-convection rate constants of oxygen and hydrogen peroxide (respectively).

sections.heading: Deposition of the ZnO layers
sections.text:
ZnO films were deposited on copper substrates by radio-frequency magnetron sputtering (Univex 350, Oerlikon) using a zinc target. Copper cylinder substrates (5 mm diameter, 4 mm height) were micro-machined from commercially available rods (purity > 99.95%, GoodFellow) to fit the RRDE setup. The substrates were grinded (Stuers Tegramin-25) with SiC paper (P2500 and P4000 for 60 s each) using water as a lubricant. The finishing of the surface was done with a polishing cloth (MasterTex, Buehler) and polycrystalline diamond suspensions (3 μm and 1 μm, each for 180 s). The substrates were then ultrasonically cleaned in ethanol, rinsed in deionized water and air-dried. Samples for X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) measurements were deposited on thinner glass substrates that fit the sample holder of the analysis apparatus. The substrates (copper and glass) were not heated during deposition. The working chamber was vacuumed to reach a base pressure of 4.8 x10-7 mbar. The substrates were fixed at a distance of ca. 10 cm parallel to the zinc target surface. A mixture of argon and oxygen reactive gases (with a relatively high oxygen flux: Ar:O2 20:3 sccm) was utilized. The gas purities were 99.9996% for Argon and 99.9995% for O2. Pre-sputtering was carried out for 30 min to clean and equilibrate the target surface prior to deposition. The same conditions were used for pre-sputtering and sputtering, except deposition time. During deposition, the total pressure was kept at 1.7 x10-2 mbar. The input power at the target was fixed at 250 W.

sections.heading: Characterization of the ZnO layers
sections.text: X-ray diffraction (XRD) was done to analyse the crystalline structure of the ZnO layers using PANalytical Empyrean apparatus with CuK radiation (1.5408 Å). Raman microscopy provided information on the chemical composition and the crystallinity of the films. Measurements were carried out using a confocal Raman spectrometer Horiba-Jobin Yvon Xplora Plus equipped with a TE-cooled CCD camera (1024 x 256 pixels). A 532 nm laser source was used with a x100 objective and a 1200 groves per mm grating in mapping mode (40 x 40 µm² with 1 µm step). The surface of the layers was analysed by XPS using an Al-Kα X-ray source (Thermo VG) and a cylindrical mirror analyser (RIBER). Top-view secondary electron imaging was performed with a field emission SEM (FEI Quanta 200F) at 20 kV to characterize the surface morphology of the ZnO layers. The machine was equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDX) system from EDAX (Octane Super, with TEAM software) that enabled to determine the composition of the layers. EDX spot analyses were acquired at 20 kV (10 measurements for each analysis). The nanostructure of the ZnO layers was investigated with high resolution scanning transmission electron microscopy (STEM, FEI Talos F200X) at 200 kV. For this purpose, electron transparent TEM lamellas (thickness ca. 50 nm) were fabricated with focus ion beam. The High-Angle Annular Dark Field (HAADF) detector provided the best contrast settings for capturing the internal pore structure of the ZnO layers.

sections.heading: Electrochemical measurements
sections.text:
All the electrochemical experiments were conducted at room temperature in KOH solutions at pH = 10 +/- 0.1 with KCl 0.2 M as supporting electrolyte. The counter-electrode was a large titanium-based metallic grid placed below the working electrode. The reference electrode was a mercury/mercury oxide electrode (Hg-HgO, KOH 1M). Oxygen reduction (ORR) was investigated using chronoamperometry, potentiodynamic voltammetry and RRDE. In the RRDE setup (Pine Research Instrumentation), the ZnO disk layer (on top of the copper substrate, diameter: 5 mm) was surrounded by a concentric gold ring (width: 1 mm). The two electrodes were separated by a 0.75 mm wide Teflon gap. The collection efficiency of the ring, N, was beforehand measured to be 23 % by performing the reduction of the ferricyanide anion (from a K3Fe(CN)6 solution,10 mM) on the disk and collecting (oxidizing) the resulting ferrocyanide on the ring (not shown here). The disk and the ring currents were recorded simultaneously at fixed potentials while varying the rotation rate (between 40 and 600 rpm). The potential of the ring electrode was set at + 0.850 V (vs. Hg-

sections.heading: 3. Results and discussion
sections.text:
Figure 2 shows a typical diffractogram and a representative Raman spectrum of the asdeposited layers. The XRD spectrum (Fig. 2a) displays multiple orientations, the most important being the (002), (010) and (011), which evidences the non-textured nature of the crystalline parts of the film. Debye-Scherrer analysis yields an averaged grain size of 9 nm.
Figure 2: Analysis of the composition and the crystallinity of the as-deposited layers. (a) XRD diffractogram (note the logarithmic scale of the intensity axis); (b) Baseline-corrected Raman spectrum.
The Raman spectral signature (Fig. 2b) corresponds to zinc oxide with two major signals near 560 cm-1 and 430-440 cm-1 that are in good agreement with previous corrosion studies. [20,21] Those signals are attributed to the A1(LO) mode and to the E2H mode respectively. [39-43] The intensity ratio E2H/A1(LO) shows that a significant part of the ZnO film is in amorphous state. In combination with XRD results, it can be concluded that the layers are only partly crystalline (with no preferred orientation). Partially amorphous nanostructured ZnO with no preferred orientation was also recently found in simonkolleite/ZnO artificial patinas produced by oxidation of zinc substrates in NaCl solutions. [20] The XPS analysis of the non-textured films is shown in Figure 3. The films exhibit only the Zn and O peaks. No other impurities are observed on the surface of the samples. The O (1s) peak

The morphology of the layers was investigated with scanning electron microscopy (Figure 4). Top-view SEM micrographs (Fig. 4a) show that the ZnO films are made of a base layer on top of which one can see spherical “nodules” with a diameter of ca. 0.5 μm to 1 μm. The base layer consists of very small grains hinting at the desired nano-granular structure. Figures 4b and 4c display the HAADF-STEM cross-sectional images revealing that the layers are nanoporous with pores mostly narrower than 10 nm (with a few larger pores around 15-20 nm). Grain size is in the range of 10 nm which is consistent with the Debye-Scherrer analysis mentioned above. It is believed that the electrolyte might penetrate the pore network but, from an electrochemical kinetic point of view, ORR takes place essentially at the surface of such

Systematically, chronoamperometry at -0.7 V (OCP was ca. -0.1 V) with a rotation rate of 200 rpm was carried out as first experiment right after electrode immersion in order to evaluate the electrochemical stability of the films. A typical chronoamperometric curve is shown in Figure 5.
Figure 5: Typical chronoamperometry curve of the disk recorded at -0.7V and at a rotation rate of 200 rpm.
At the beginning of the measurement, the current density decreases sharply, which corresponds to the capacitive discharge resulting from the applied potential step from OCP to -0.7 V. Thereafter, the current density increases steadily at a rate of ca. 1-2 μA/cm2/min during ca. 40- 60 min (depending on the sample). During this period, no reliable analysis of the ORR mechanism could be done since no steady-state conditions were reached. This period is denoted “stabilization phase”. Under those conditions, the rapid measurements of disk and ring currents (as described below in Figure 8a) are considered as reliable. From the beginning to the end of the DC polarization (chronoamperometry + RRDE experiments), the current density increases by 20-50 %, depending on the sample and the duration of polarization. In order to gain more insight on the evolution of the current shown in Figure 5, SEM imaging of the surface of the films was performed before and after polarization (Figure 6). A roughening of the surface due to the development of a large number of nodules during polarization is clearly visible on the SEM micrographs (Figure 6b). The increase of current density observed during the stabilization phase can thus be ascribed to the nodule growth that leads to an increase of the electrode/electrolyte surface area. Yet one must bear in mind that, even if they have similar shape and size, the nodules from the as-deposited samples (Figure 6a) originate from the sputtering deposition while the additional nodules of the post-mortem samples (Figure 6b) are likely to be generated from a chemical or electrochemical process .

 The oxygen reduction takes place at the surface of the electrode and not in the pore
network as the latter is too resistive for the transport of electroactive species. In view of the HAADF-STEM results (Fig. 4b and 4c), this approximation is realistic.

assumed that it also applies to “moderately rough” electrodes like those described in Figure 8b). The reasonable nature of this approximation is also supported by the fact that the determination of the NId

Typical experimental RRDE data is presented in Figure 8. The disk and ring current are recorded under pseudo-steady-state conditions at fixed potential while varying the rotation rates. In Figure 8a, Ir is divided by the collection efficiency N (23%). It represents the ring current that would be generated if this efficiency was 100%. The NId
Ir vs. Ω ½ plots for several non-textured ZnO films at -0.7 V and -0.9 V are shown in
Figure 8b. The good linear regressions validate the proposed model along with its assumptions and approximations. Although there is some scattering in the results from one sample to naother, the intercepts on the y-axis led to rather reproducible values. The ratio k1
k2 was 1.1 to
1.6 at -0.7 V and 1.3 to 2.2 at - 0.9 V. Thus there is a slight prevalence of the direct oxygen reduction (pathway k1). The results indicate that both the direct and indirect pathways contribute to the reduction of oxygen and none of them can be neglected. In the reports of the literature about ORR investigated on zinc with the RRDE technique, the trend is that the reaction mechanism is potential-dependent (in alkaline and near-neutral electrolytes). [5,45] On passive zinc (i.e. covered by a few nanometers of ZnO) and low cathodic overpotentials, a twoelectron reaction was found, producing only hydrogen peroxide (no direct reduction). This corresponds to the step k2 of our reaction mechanism. With increasing negative potentials, the contribution of the direct reduction (step k1) increases until it becomes the unique reaction (with no hydrogen peroxide produced). This “switch” of reaction mechanism is associated with the passive-active transition of the zinc surface when the potential goes more negative. [16] Thus it appears that the “thick” ZnO films of this study behave quite differently with both the production of OH- (step k1) and hydrogen peroxide (step k2) even far from the equilibrium potential.

The superior activity of sputtered ZnO can also be seen in the smaller overpotentials to reach the onset of the oxygen reduction “wave”: ca. -100 mV for sputtered ZnO compared to ca. -500 mV for electrodeposited ZnO. Goux et al. reported similarly large ORR overpotentials for electrodeposited ZnO in near-neutral KCl 0.1M solution at 70 °C. [18] Those findings show that ZnO can have very different cathodic activities depending on the sample history. To the best of our knowledge, the electrochemical activity results of the present study on sputtered nano-granular ZnO used as model material are the first ones that support the hypothesis that “some type(s)” of ZnO may act as efficient cathodes and could promote the degradation of zinc-based protective coatings, as mentioned in the introduction.

sections.heading: 4. Conclusions
sections.text:
600-800 nm thin non-textured ZnO films were successfully produced by rf-magnetron sputtering and used as model system to investigate alkaline oxygen reduction using the rotating-ring disk electrode technique. The layers were nanoporous with a sufficiently narrow pore network to consider that oxygen reduction took place essentially at the surface of the layers. Under DC polarization, the ZnO films became rougher due to the development of numerous oxygen-rich nodules on top of a base layer that held the nominal ZnO composition. Nevertheless XRD and Raman spectroscopy could only evidence the presence of ZnO in the as-deposited and post-mortem states. A reaction mechanism was proposed for oxygen reduction accounting for direct and indirect pathways in parallel. Using experimental data collected with the RRDE technique, the ratio k1
k2
(ratio of direct over indirect reduction) could be evaluated. The direct reduction was shown to be dominant but the indirect redaction could not be neglected. The roughness of the electrode impeded the determination of the mean number of exchanged electrons using the KouteckyLevich equation. However it was possible to determine that indirect reduction pathway did not stop at the production of hydrogen peroxide. The latter is further reduced to OH- anions and/or decomposed into oxygen molecules. Compared to other nano-granular ZnO films reported in the literature, the layers of the present study exhibited a significantly higher activity towards ORR with low overpotentials. This shows there is great interest in investigating in the future the complex and still poorly known relationships between oxygen reduction activity and the numerous parameters that define a

sections.text:
The oxygen reduction reaction (ORR) was investigated in alkaline electrolyte on radiofrequency sputtered ZnO films with nano-granular structure. A combination of rotating ringdisk electrode experiments and reaction mechanism modelling showed that both the direct pathway (with no intermediate species) and the indirect pathway (producing hydrogen peroxide) are active. Furthermore, this type of ZnO exhibits high activity towards ORR.

metadata.abstractText: Zinc oxide (ZnO) films with nano-granular structure were deposited by radio-frequency magnetron sputtering. The absence of preferred orientation was verified by XRD. HAADFSTEM micrographs revealed a nanoporous structure with pore size and grain size around 10 nm. The narrowness of the pores enabled to approximate that oxygen reduction takes place at the surface of the layers. During cathodic polarization, the surface of the electrodes became rougher due to the development of nodules on the surface. The ZnO electrodes exhibit a high activity towards oxygen reduction in KOH solution (pH = 10). Rotating ring-disk electrode measurements coupled with reaction modelling allowed to quantitatively demonstrate that the direct reduction prevailed with the indirect pathway being active as well.
